item.title: Call for Paper - Embodied Intelligence Empowering Smart Manufacturing
item.description:
Embodied Intelligence Empowering Smart Manufacturing Submission deadline: 31 August 2025 Embodied Intelligence (EI) is a key enabler of flexible and efficient manufacturing in smart manufacturing. EI enhances the perception, memory, cognition, reasoning, decision-making, planning, control, and iterative evolution capabilities within smart manufacturing systems. However, existing AI methods designed for specific tasks may lack adaptability and learning evolution capabilities needed to address personalization. The limited knowledge sharing and collaboration among independent AI models result hinders collective intelligence. AI methods that rely on fixed models and predefined rules are not easily adaptable to unpredictable scenarios in flexible, dynamic, and unstructured manufacturing environments. In addition, human-machine collaboration in smart manufacturing remains inefficient, and manufacturing equipment demands more intelligent collaborative control methods. The standalone equipment and information exchange in current smart manufacturing systems do not fully support the implementation of embodied intelligence technologies. To elevate the intelligence of smart manufacturing, this special issue aims at exploring technological advancements and applications of embodied intelligence-driven smart manufacturing. It will address key technical challenges in areas such as multimodal fusion, machine learning algorithms, human-computer interaction, and collaboration. These advancements are crucial to the progress of smart manufacturing.

Special Issue Topics

The topics covered in this special issue include, but are not limited to, the following research areas and technologies:

  • Human-machine interaction and collaboration based on embodied intelligence
  • Embodied intelligence-based scheduling and dispatching
  • Intelligent operation and maintenance methods for equipment based on multimodal data
  • Digital twin modeling methods for embodied intelligent robots
  • Multimodal industrial data collection and fusion
  • Large-scale multimodal data communication networks in smart manufacturing
  • Multi-agent collaboration and collective intelligence in smart manufacturing
  • Pretraining methods for large-scale multimodal models in smart manufacturing
  • Industrial knowledge integration for embodied intelligence
  • Control system design for manufacturing equipment driven by embodied intelligence
  • Embodied intelligence in self-evolution of manufacturing equipment control systems

Guest editors

Jiafu Wan, PhD South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China Email: mejwan@scut.edu.cn

Yuqian Lu, PhD The University of Auckland, Aucland, New Zealand Email: yuqian.lu@auckland.ac.nz

Andrew Kusiak, PhD The University of Iowa, Iowa City, Iowa, USA Email: andrew-kusiak@uiowa.edu

Meikang Qiu, PhD Augusta University, Augusta, Georgia, USA Email: qiumeikang@ieee.org

Manuscript submission information:

The journal submission system (Editorial ManagerÂ®) will be open for submissions to our Special Issue from March 01, 2025. When submitting your manuscript please select the article type VSI: EI - Smart Manufacturing.

Important dates

  • Submission Portal Open: March 01, 2025
  • Final Manuscript Submission Deadline: August 31, 2025
  • Editorial Acceptance Deadline: November 30, 2025

item.title: Groundbreaking Research in Manufacturing Quality Control from Karen Wang
item.description:
In a significant advancement for the manufacturing industry, Karen Wang, a master’s student at the University of Auckland, has developed an innovative approach to root cause analysis of product defects. This breakthrough came as part of her one-year master’s study, conducted in collaboration with AspectPT Ltd.

Wang’s research introduces the product-wise Ensemble Bayesian Network (EBN), a robust and intelligent method for identifying the root causes of manufacturing defects. This novel approach combines Bayesian Networks with ensemble learning techniques, offering a more reliable and interpretable solution to a long-standing challenge in quality control.

The study, co-authored with Chao Liu from Aston University and Yuqian Lu from the University of Auckland, demonstrates significant improvements in acquiring causal knowledge, identifying root causes with probabilities, and predicting quality risks in production. Tested with real-world data from the plastics industry, the EBN method shows promise for enhancing manufacturing quality and productivity across various sectors.

This collaboration between academia and industry showcases the potential for student-led research to drive meaningful innovations in the manufacturing landscape. AspectPT Ltd’s involvement underscores the immediate practical applications of Wang’s work, bridging the gap between theoretical research and industry needs.

As manufacturers worldwide seek to optimize their processes and reduce defects, Wang’s contribution represents a timely and valuable tool in the pursuit of excellence in product quality.

For more information on the work, please visit our open access full paper.

item.title: IJPR Top Trending Article on Industrial Knowledge Graph.
item.description: Huge congratulations to Dr. Bin Zhou and Prof. Jinsong Bao to this excellent joint work on developing innovative machine learning algorithms to extract knowledge from industrial time series data. This paper has been recognized as a Top Trending Article for 2023 at International Journal of Production Research. We are proud of this achievement from our student group (Dr. Bin Zhou was a PhD student at the time of publication) and long-term collaboration with Prof. Bao.

item.title: HA-ViD paper accepted at NeurIPS 2023
item.description:
We are pleased to announce the acceptance of our paper, “HA-ViD: A Human Assembly Video Dataset for Comprehensive Assembly Knowledge Understanding” at the esteemed NeurIPS conference. This achievement marks a milestone in our journey toward understanding the comprehensive knowledge of assembly applications such as human-robot collaboration, robot skill learning and assembly process monitoring.

HA-ViD captures the essence of industrial human assembly scenarios through the designed Generic Assembly Box, 3-stage progressive assembly setup and consistent human-robot shared annotations. The applications of this work enables research towards understanding natural human behaviours, progressive knowledge acquisition and two-hand collaboration patterns during assembly.

For more information on HA-ViD, please visit our project website

item.title: RCIM Best Paper Award
item.description:
The Best Paper is awarded each year to the RCIM paper published in the past seven-year with the highest number of citations measured in Scopus over the past five years. This is a significant achievement for our work on Smart Manufacturing.

Published version / Preprint version
